Abstract: This study explores the dynamic interplay between personal evolution and professional development within the field of archaeology, focusing on the integration of feminist practices, digital methodologies, and middle range research. Through an autobiographical lens, it examines the author's journey of shifting and pivoting standpoints in the context of Neolithic archaeology and European prehistory. The narrative underscores the importance of acknowledging inspirations and influences that shape one's academic trajectory, highlighting how diverse perspectives can enrich the construction of the past. By weaving together personal experiences with broader disciplinary trends, this work contributes to the history of archaeology, offering insights into the transformative potential of embracing interdisciplinary approaches and reflective practice in understanding human history.
